hints_html:
First notice that the question is asking for the first 5 terms NOT the first 5 nonzero terms. Thus, it’s possible to grind this out simply by taking derivatives.

The Taylor Series Formula about 0 is given by

\(\displaystyle F(x) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{F^{(n)}(0)x^n}{n!}\)

When taking derivatives, don’t forget that your first function is the function defined by the integral and that you’ll have to use the chain rule.

(Alternate Solution) If you want, you can start with the Taylor expansion of \(\displaystyle \ln(1 + x)\) and go from there.

The Taylor expansion is given by

\(\displaystyle \ln(1 + x) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{x^n}{n}\).
hints_latex:
First notice that the question is asking for the first 5 terms NOT the
first 5 nonzero terms. Thus, it's possible to grind this out simply by
taking derivatives.

The Taylor Series Formula about 0 is given by

$\displaystyle F(x) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{F^{(n)}(0)x^n}{n!}$

When taking derivatives, don't forget that your first function is the
function defined by the integral and that you'll have to use the chain
rule.

(Alternate Solution) If you want, you can start with the Taylor
expansion of $\displaystyle \ln(1 + x)$ and go from there.

The Taylor expansion is given by

$\displaystyle \ln(1 + x) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{x^n}{n}$.
hints_raw:
First notice that the question is asking for the first 5 terms NOT the first 5 nonzero terms. Thus, it's possible to grind this out simply by taking derivatives.
The Taylor Series Formula about 0 is given by

<math> \displaystyle F(x) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{F^{(n)}(0)x^n}{n!}</math>
When taking derivatives, don't forget that your first function is the function defined by the integral and that you'll have to use the chain rule.
(Alternate Solution) If you want, you can start with the Taylor expansion of <math> \displaystyle \ln(1 + x)</math> and go from there.
The Taylor expansion is given by

<math> \displaystyle \ln(1 + x) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{x^n}{n}</math>.
sols_html:
We mechanically plug in the derivatives to the Taylor series formula given by

\(\displaystyle F(x) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{F^{(n)}(0)x^n}{n!}\)

where

\(\displaystyle F(x) = \int_{0}^{x}\ln(1 + s^2)\,ds\).

Now, we have

\(\displaystyle F(0) = \int_{0}^{0}\ln(1 + s^2)\,ds = 0\).

Using the FTC, we get

\(\displaystyle F'(0) = \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\int_{0}^{x}\ln(1 + s^2)\,ds = \ln(1 + x^2)\big|_{x=0} = \ln(1) = 0\).

The next derivative is (via the chain rule)

\(\displaystyle F''(0) = \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\ln(1 + x^2) = \left.\frac{2x}{1 + x^2}\right|_{x=0} = 0\).

The next derivative is (via the quotient rule)

\(\displaystyle F'''(0) = \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\frac{2x}{1 + x^2}= \left.\frac{2(1+x^2) - (2x)^2}{(1 + x^2)^2}\right|_{x=0} = 2\).

The last derivative is

\[\begin{aligned} F''''(0) &= \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\frac{2(1+x^2) - (2x)^2}{(1 + x^2)^2} \\ &= \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\frac{2-2x^2}{(1 + x^2)^2}\\ &= \left.\frac{-4x(1 + x^2)^2 - 2(1-x^2)\cdot2(1+x^2)(2x)}{(1 + x^2)^4}\right|_{x=0} \\ &= 0 \end{aligned}\]

.

Thus, the fourth Taylor polynomial is

\(\displaystyle T_{4}(x) = \frac{x^3}{3}\)

as required.

Starting with

\(\displaystyle \ln(1 + x) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{x^n}{n}\)

We see that

\(\displaystyle \ln(1 + s^2) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{s^{2n}}{n}\).

Integrating yields

\(\displaystyle \int_{0}^{x}\ln(1 + s^2) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1} \int_{0}^{x}\frac{s^{2n}}{n} = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{x^{2n+1}}{n(2n+1)}\)

Plugging in the first few values yields

\(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{x^{2n+1}}{n(2n+1)} = \frac{x^{3}}{3} - \frac{x^5}{10} + ...\)

Since the question is seeking \(\displaystyle T_{4}(x)\), we have that

\(\displaystyle T_{4}(x) = \frac{x^3}{3}\)

as required.
sols_latex:
We mechanically plug in the derivatives to the Taylor series formula
given by

$\displaystyle F(x) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{F^{(n)}(0)x^n}{n!}$

where

$\displaystyle F(x) = \int_{0}^{x}\ln(1 + s^2)\,ds$.

Now, we have

$\displaystyle F(0) = \int_{0}^{0}\ln(1 + s^2)\,ds = 0$.

Using the FTC, we get

$\displaystyle F'(0) = \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\int_{0}^{x}\ln(1 + s^2)\,ds = \ln(1 + x^2)\big|_{x=0} = \ln(1) = 0$.

The next derivative is (via the chain rule)

$\displaystyle F''(0) = \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\ln(1 + x^2) = \left.\frac{2x}{1 + x^2}\right|_{x=0} = 0$.

The next derivative is (via the quotient rule)

$\displaystyle F'''(0) = \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\frac{2x}{1 + x^2}= \left.\frac{2(1+x^2) - (2x)^2}{(1 + x^2)^2}\right|_{x=0} = 2$.

The last derivative is

\begin{align*}
F''''(0) &= \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\frac{2(1+x^2) - (2x)^2}{(1 + x^2)^2} \\
&= \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\frac{2-2x^2}{(1 + x^2)^2}\\
&= \left.\frac{-4x(1 + x^2)^2 - 2(1-x^2)\cdot2(1+x^2)(2x)}{(1 + x^2)^4}\right|_{x=0} \\
&= 0 
\end{align*}.

Thus, the fourth Taylor polynomial is

$\displaystyle T_{4}(x) = \frac{x^3}{3}$

as required.

Starting with

$\displaystyle \ln(1 + x) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{x^n}{n}$

We see that

$\displaystyle \ln(1 + s^2) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{s^{2n}}{n}$.

Integrating yields

$\displaystyle \int_{0}^{x}\ln(1 + s^2) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1} \int_{0}^{x}\frac{s^{2n}}{n} = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{x^{2n+1}}{n(2n+1)}$

Plugging in the first few values yields

$\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{x^{2n+1}}{n(2n+1)} = \frac{x^{3}}{3} - \frac{x^5}{10} + ...$

Since the question is seeking $\displaystyle T_{4}(x)$, we have that

$\displaystyle T_{4}(x) = \frac{x^3}{3}$

as required.

<math> \displaystyle F(x) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{F^{(n)}(0)x^n}{n!}</math>

where 

<math> \displaystyle F(x) = \int_{0}^{x}\ln(1 + s^2)\,ds</math>.

Now, we have 

<math> \displaystyle F(0) = \int_{0}^{0}\ln(1 + s^2)\,ds = 0</math>.

Using the FTC, we get

<math> \displaystyle F'(0) = \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\int_{0}^{x}\ln(1 + s^2)\,ds = \ln(1 + x^2)\big|_{x=0} = \ln(1) = 0</math>.

The next derivative is (via the chain rule)

<math> \displaystyle F''(0) = \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\ln(1 + x^2) = \left.\frac{2x}{1 + x^2}\right|_{x=0} = 0 </math>.

The next derivative is (via the quotient rule)

<math> \displaystyle F'''(0) = \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\frac{2x}{1 + x^2}= \left.\frac{2(1+x^2) - (2x)^2}{(1 + x^2)^2}\right|_{x=0} = 2 </math>.

The last derivative is

<math> 
\begin{align}
F''''(0) &= \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\frac{2(1+x^2) - (2x)^2}{(1 + x^2)^2} \\
&= \left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{x=0}\frac{2-2x^2}{(1 + x^2)^2}\\
&= \left.\frac{-4x(1 + x^2)^2 - 2(1-x^2)\cdot2(1+x^2)(2x)}{(1 + x^2)^4}\right|_{x=0} \\
&= 0 
\end{align}
</math>.

Thus, the fourth Taylor polynomial is

<math> \displaystyle T_{4}(x) = \frac{x^3}{3}</math>

as required.
Starting with

<math> \displaystyle \ln(1 + x) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{x^n}{n}</math>

We see that

<math> \displaystyle \ln(1 + s^2) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{s^{2n}}{n}</math>.

Integrating yields

<math> \displaystyle \int_{0}^{x}\ln(1 + s^2) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1} \int_{0}^{x}\frac{s^{2n}}{n} = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{x^{2n+1}}{n(2n+1)}</math>


Plugging in the first few values yields

<math> \displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\frac{x^{2n+1}}{n(2n+1)} = \frac{x^{3}}{3} - \frac{x^5}{10} + ...</math>

Since the question is seeking <math> \displaystyle T_{4}(x)</math>, we have that

<math> \displaystyle T_{4}(x) = \frac{x^3}{3}</math>

as required.
statement_html: Taylor Series: Find the first five terms of the Taylor series centred at 0 for \(\displaystyle F(x) = \int_{0}^{x}\ln(1 + s^2)\,ds\) i.e. the polynomial \(\displaystyle T_4(x)\) with \(\displaystyle x^4\) the highest power of x.
statement_latex:
\textbf{Taylor Series:} Find the first five terms of the Taylor series
centred at 0 for $\displaystyle F(x) = \int_{0}^{x}\ln(1 + s^2)\,ds$
i.e. the polynomial $\displaystyle T_4(x)$ with $\displaystyle x^4$ the
highest power of \emph{x}.
statement_raw: '''Taylor Series:''' Find the first five terms of the Taylor series centred at 0 for <math> \displaystyle F(x) = \int_{0}^{x}\ln(1 + s^2)\,ds</math> i.e. the polynomial <math> \displaystyle T_4(x)</math> with <math> \displaystyle x^4</math> the highest power of ''x''.
